quoteFirst: She waited for a little and then rose from her bed. She drew the window-curtains aside and by the glimmering light which came into the room, was able to read the dial of her watch. It was
quoteLast: of the morning. She immediately lighted her candle and went to rouse her father. Her door opened upon the landing, it is the first door upon the left hand side as you mount the stairs; the big drawing-room opens on to the landing too, but faces the stairs. Mrs.
title: Ensign Knightley, and Other Stories
author: Mason, A. E. W. (Alfred Edward Woodley), 1865-1948

quoteFirst: The French general entered the battery in a fury; demanding sharply who had given the signal, his wrath changed into astonishment when he was told no signal had been given, and his astonishment into vexation when he learned that General Mayran had mistaken a military rocket, fired from the Mamelon, for the signal to assault! The unity and suddenness of the assault were thus destroyed; but General Pélissier, without hesitation, ordered the rockets to be fired, and, at
quoteLast: , the clustering stars of fire hung for a moment up in the black sky, and then paled and vanished. The French troops dashed out in the gloom to the assault.
title:
Cassell's History of England, Vol. 6 (of 8)
From the Death of Sir Robert Peel to the Illness of the Prince of Wales
author: Anonymous

quoteTime: seven minutes past three in the afternoon
quoteLast: , Cecily Thorogood, that very self-possessed and prettily-clad young woman, was seated in a deck-chair on the saloon-deck of a 6,000-ton liner; an American magazine was open in front of her, under cover of which she was exploring the contents of a box of chocolates with the practised eye of the expert, in quest of a particular species which contained crystallised ginger and found favour in her sight.
title: The Long Trick
author: Bartimeus, 1886-1967

title: Ensign Knightley, and Other Stories

quoteLast: our artillery stopped, and the rattle of machine-guns stood out in the comparative silence.
title: The Tank Corps
author: Williams-Ellis, Clough, 1883-1978; Williams-Ellis, Amabel, 1894-1984; Elles, Hugh Jamieson, 1880-1945 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteTime: seven minutes past three in the afternoon
quoteLast: , Cecily Thorogood, that very self-possessed and prettily-clad young woman, was seated in a deck-chair on the saloon-deck of a 6,000-ton liner; an American magazine was open in front of her, under cover of which she was exploring the contents of a box of chocolates with the practised eye of the expert, in quest of a particular species which contained crystallised ginger and found favour in her sight.

quoteLast: , Penrod opened the door of the largest “music store” in town.
title: Penrod and Sam
author: Tarkington, Booth, 1869-1946

quoteLast: , Wednesday, October 11, 1899. The time is up! Without a doubt the first shot in the war is being fired to-day in South Africa at this moment. Some man had to be the first to fall; he has fallen.
title: Mark Twain: A Biography. Volume II, Part 2: 1886-1900
author: Paine, Albert Bigelow, 1861-1937

quoteFirst: Commander Nerger shaped his course so as to meet this steamer but still give him the impression that we were en route from the Cape to Colombo. At 3:05 P.M. the steamer was right abreast, She was a fine big Class A Japanese passenger steamer, deeply loaded, and I could see passengers on her saloon deck. At
quoteLast: the _Wolf_ broke out the Imperial Navy flag and signalled for the _Hitachi Maru_ to stop and not use her wireless, also dropped a shot across the _Hitachi's_ bow. When the _Hitachi_ failed to stop, the _Wolf_ fired another shot closer to her bow.
title: Ten months in a German raider
author: Cameron, John Stanley; Brown, Cyril, 1887-1949 [Editor]

quoteFirst: As he is an evening star, the most convenient opportunities are afforded for obtaining a fine view. He rises on the 1st at
quoteLast: , and sets on the 2nd at 5:43 a. m.; on the 15th rises at 2:04 p. m., and sets the following morning at 4:40; on the 30th, rises at 1:07 p. m., and sets on the 31st at 3:43 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, January 1885, No. 4
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
